It was funny when the girl turned into a Red Panda and made funny sounds. It's your right as a parent of young children to filter what media they consume, but don't write the movie off just because a few pearls were clutched. (11/11)

If your child ends up having hard questions after watching it? Good! That's what you're there for: to be able to help them navigate hard questions!

I loved Turning Red, as did my kids. Their biggest takeaway from the movie? (10/11)

It's best to come up with a game plan on how to lovingly address those times when they come rather than hide your head in the sand and pretend they won't.

The movie is lighthearted and fun, yet it also hits hard about what growing up is like. (9/11)

Just because a character in a movie has a bad attitude doesn't mean your child will imitate it. Another fun fact, no matter how perfect a parent you are, your children will still probably break your rules, especially as teenagers. (8/11)

Here's a hard fact about movies: they present situations that we do not always want kids to mimic. I don't want my kids wandering through doors with strangers, yet I didn't think Monsters Inc would prompt my children to do so. (7/11)

Also, many in those circles are worked up about the movie "promoting rebellion." If you walked away more worried about the daughter's rebellion than anything else, you might just be the overbearing mom. (6/11)

Do that many people really not remember what it's like being a teenager? You get crushes, you talk about those crushes with your friends. That's not inappropriate, that's just adolescence. Why is it ok when teenage boys talk about their crushes but not teenage girls? (5/11)

And pre-teens will thank you for having a conversation about it with them instead of trying to hide from it.

What's also very curious is how these same people are alarmed over a 13-year-old girl having crushes and talking about boys being cute. (4/11)

Half the population gets them for decades of their lives. It's very interesting to see which people are offended by this part of the movie. Young kids probably won't pick up on the "red monster" having a double meaning of menstruation. (3/11)

Throw in some zany cartoon antics and a transformation into an animal, and you have classic Disney/Pixar fare.

The analogy to puberty (and periods in particular) is clear, but what's not clear is why the topic of periods is still taboo in this day and age. (2/11)

🧵 It is extremely telling of a certain Christian subculture that the new Pixar movie #TurningRed has sparked such controversy. The movie is a charming coming-of-age story in which a 13-year-old girl with an excessively overbearing mother begins to go through a big change. (1/11)

In the 21st century, there are a huge number of tools that allow authors to self-publish or serialize their works. Among the most accessible and flexible tools I’ve found recently is Substack, where authors of non-fiction and fiction alike can build an audience.

Renowned authors such as Charles Dickens, Alexandre Dumas, and Agatha Christie made use of serialized publishing. In fact, some of the most well-known authors in literary history published their works almost exclusively in a serialized format.

Publishing a novel with one of the big-name publishers is either a result of good connections or pure luck. Publishers want a sure thing. A reliable return on their investment. That's what led me to think about serialized storytelling on @SubstackInc

So all of this "virtual church isn't church" stuff misses the entire point of the church to begin with because corporate worship gatherings are only a sliver of what church is about. And if that's the only way your church manifests, it's probably not a healthy church.

Whether that community is found in small groups during the week, informal gatherings throughout the area, or digital formats like Facebook groups, if your church is building real community, you won't have to beg/demand for people to come back to your weekly worship services.
